importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The investigation into John Bolton's handling of classified information began in 2022 after his emails were hacked by Iran.
The FBI's Iran hack investigation into Bolton started in 2021 under the Biden administration, leading to the current indictment.
The indictment was formally announced on October 16, 2025, marking a pivotal moment in political and legal developments concerning former Trump administration figures.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The investigation into Bolton began in 2021 under the Biden administration and culminated in the indictment in late 2025, reflecting a sustained federal effort to address classified information violations.

keyTakeAways: John Bolton, former national security adviser to President Donald Trump, was indicted by a federal grand jury in Maryland on October 16, 2025.
Bolton faces 18 counts—eight for transmission and 10 for retention—of national defense information, including classified material at the TOP SECRET level.
The indictment alleges that Bolton created and shared over a thousand pages of handwritten diary entries, which included secure and classified information from his time in the White House.
Bolton allegedly used personal email accounts (AOL, Google) to transmit classified information to family members who had no security clearance.
The FBI investigation began in 2021 after Iran hacked Bolton’s email accounts, and he allegedly failed to disclose this to the FBI.
The case is part of a broader pattern of targeting political opponents under the Trump administration, with Bolton calling the charges a political weaponization of the Justice Department.
Bolton claims the charges are politically motivated, citing that no charges were filed during the Biden years despite prior scrutiny of his 2020 memoir.
The case has the support of career prosecutors and investigators, distinguishing it from politically charged cases like those involving James Comey or Letitia James.
If proven, the charges represent a serious violation of federal law, potentially more severe than similar cases involving other high-ranking officials.
The case is being handled by US District Judge Theodore Chuang, appointed by Barack Obama in 2014.

summaryOfNewsArticle: John Bolton, former national security adviser to President Donald Trump, was indicted in Maryland on October 16, 2025, on 18 counts related to the transmission and retention of top-secret classified information. The charges stem from a 2021 FBI investigation triggered by an Iran hack of Bolton’s email accounts, which revealed that he shared over a thousand pages of handwritten diary entries—containing classified material—from his time in the White House. Allegedly, Bolton used personal email accounts (AOL, Google) to transmit this information to family members who had no security clearance. The case, now being overseen by Judge Theodore Chuang, is distinct from politically charged prosecutions like those of James Comey or Letitia James, as it has maintained support from career prosecutors. Bolton claims the charges are politically motivated, citing that no action was taken during the Biden administration despite prior scrutiny of his memoir. The indictment raises serious legal implications, potentially more severe than similar cases involving other officials, due to the active dissemination of top-secret material to non-clearance individuals.
title: Indictment of Former Trump National Security Adviser John Bolton on Classified Information Charges
